metadata.title: ProRes vs H.264 2025: Which Video Codec for YouTube
metadata.description: Compare ProRes and H.264 codecs. Which is best for recording and editing YouTube content?

hero.headline: ProRes vs H.264
hero.subheadline: Quality vs file size. Which codec for your YouTube workflow?

sections.content: ProRes and H.264 serve different purposes. ProRes is designed for editing—high quality, large files. H.264 is designed for delivery—compressed, efficient. Understanding when to use each improves your workflow and final quality.

content.title: Recording Original Footage
content.description: If camera supports it and storage permits. Maximum quality retained.

content.title: Heavy Color Grading
content.description: 10-bit color handles grading better. Less banding, more flexibility.

content.title: Smoother Editing
content.description: Less CPU decoding. Timeline scrubs smoothly. Faster editing.

content.title: Final Export for YouTube
content.description: YouTube prefers H.264. Good quality at manageable size.

content.title: Storage Limited
content.description: 10x smaller files than ProRes. Practical for most.

content.title: Most Camera Recording
content.description: Most cameras record H.264/H.265. Practical default.

sections.title: Optimal Workflow
content: Record in best quality camera offers
Transcode to ProRes for editing (if needed)
Export to H.264 for YouTube upload

faq.question: Should I record in ProRes?
faq.answer: If camera supports it and storage permits, yes—best quality. Most cameras don't offer it. Use highest quality your camera provides.

faq.question: What about H.265/HEVC?
faq.answer: Better compression than H.264 but harder to edit. Good for final delivery if YouTube supports it. ProRes still better for editing.

faq.question: Does YouTube prefer ProRes uploads?
faq.answer: YouTube accepts both but recommends H.264. ProRes won't look better—YouTube re-encodes everything. H.264 uploads faster.

faq.question: My computer struggles with H.264 editing?
faq.answer: Create proxy files. Edit with proxies, link to originals for export. Or transcode to ProRes/DNxHR for editing.
